            Marking notes
       Remarques pour la notation
        Notas para la corrección

November / Novembre / Noviembre de 2023


                     English A: literature
                     Anglais A : littérature
                      Inglés A: Literatura


         Higher level and standard level
        Niveau supérieur et niveau moyen
           Nivel Superior y Nivel Medio

                  Paper / Épreuve / Prueba 1

toutefois s’y limiter, des éditeurs, des professeurs particuliers, des services de tutorat ou
d’aide aux études, des établissements de préparation à l’enseignement supérieur, des

                                               –3–                           8823 – 0046M/0047M


General marking instructions

 These notes to examiners are intended only as guidelines to assist marking. They are not offered
 as an exhaustive and fixed set of features which all answers must include.

 Answers which do not follow the approach suggested in the guiding question, but have provided
 an alternative formal or technical focus should be rewarded appropriately in line with the
 assessment criteria.


Instructions générales pour la notation

 Ces notes ne sont que simples lignes directrices pour aider les examinateurs lors de la notation.
 Elles ne peuvent en aucun cas être considérées comme un ensemble fixe et exhaustif de
 caractéristiques que les réponses doivent présenter.

 Les réponses qui ne suivent pas l’approche suggérée dans la question d’orientation, mais qui
 ont adopté un autre angle technique ou formel doivent être récompensées de manière
 appropriée, conformément aux critères d’évaluation.


Instrucciones generales para la corrección

 El objetivo de estas notas para los examinadores es servir de directrices a fin de ayudar en la
 corrección. No deben considerarse un conjunto fijo y exhaustivo de características que deban
 estar presentes en todas las respuestas.

 Las respuestas que no sigan el enfoque recomendado en la pregunta de orientación, pero
 posean un enfoque alternativo, de carácter formal o técnico, también deberán ser valoradas
 de acuerdo con los criterios de evaluación.
                                               –4–                            8823 – 0046M/0047M


1.

                                           Literary form

                                        Prose fiction: novel

                          Elements of the text significant for analysis

 • descriptions of the angry crowd: ‘a thousand angry eyes’, ‘savage satisfaction of the rolling
   angry murmur’, ‘enraged beyond measure’, ‘wild beating and raging’, ‘hundreds of infuriated
   men and reckless boys’, ‘stormy passions’, ‘angry sea of men’, ‘troop of animals’
 • repetition of ‘cruel’ and ‘thoughtless’
 • verbs that denote violence
 • comparison to aggressive animals (‘gaunt as wolves, and mad for prey’)
 • description of facial expressions (‘livid with rage’, ‘the countenances, so fell not a moment
   before, now looked irresolute’, ‘her eyes smiting them with flaming arrows of reproach’)
 • use of free indirect discourse: how we are viewing this from Margaret’s point of view; how she
   is torn between a sympathetic understanding of the workers’ struggles and fear for Thornton
 • development of tension (‘each was urging the other on to some immediate act of personal
   violence’, ‘For she stood between them and their enemy’)
 • characterisation of Mr Thornton and how this contrasts with the workers
 • the threat to Thornton’s life
 • contrast between emotions and reason (‘the stormy passions would have passed their
   bounds, and swept away all barriers of reason, or apprehension of consequence’)
 • contrast between silence and noise (‘rolling angry murmur’, ‘stony silence’, ‘momentary hush’,
   ‘She could not speak’)
 • comparison to river about to burst its banks
 • the portrayal of the two named characters, including the contrast of male/female: Thornton’s
   immobility (‘still as a statue’) versus the energetic actions of Margaret (‘threw the window wide
   open’, ‘tore her bonnet off’, ‘she had lifted the great iron bar of the door with an imperious
   force – had thrown the door open wide’)
 • importance of the descriptions of time in relation to the potential for the situation to explode
   into violence (‘in an instant all would be uproar’, ‘in another instant the stormy passions...’)
 • significance of references to weapons and explosions, including the ‘heavy wooden clogs’,
   ‘flaming arrows of reproach, ‘spark to the gunpowder’ (note the mixing of literal and
   metaphorical)
 • the violence of the emotions portrayed in the text
 • vulnerable position of Margaret at the end of the extract, despite the strength and anger she
   shows.
                                               –5–                           8823 – 0046M/0047M


2.

                                          Literary form

                                              Drama

                          Elements of the text significant for analysis

 • the use of gestures and lack of movement (especially the final stage direction), and the
   balance in dialogue between the two characters to suggest the tense, complex mother-
   daughter relationship
 • Valentina’s use of questions and absolute pronouncements gives her power; how Valentina
   disparages Sophia, her curt dismissal and contemptuous assessment of her daughter (‘You
   understand nothing’); her repetition of ‘You think...’
 • the manner in which Sophia has prepared for this conversation, but her difficulties in actually
   speaking to her mother
 • the significance of the stage directions: how these suggest the struggle within Sophia and the
   dominance of Valentina
 • the ways in which the stage directions suggest a tension between what is felt and what is
   spoken
 • the way in which Valentina asserts her power (‘Little Sophia’)
 • despite Sophia’s statement that they ‘must speak as equals’, it is clear that her mother often
   puts her in a subordinate position
 • contrast between emotional proximity and emotional distance
 • use of imperatives
 • Sophia’s use of short sentences to stress her points
 • the ease with which the mother speaks contrasted with the difficulties experienced by her
   daughter
 • how Valentina asks for her daughter to speak and the way Sophia is unable to communicate
 • how Sophia asserts her power contrasted with her wavering determination: these indicate the
   shifts in the power dynamic between the daughter and her mother
 • how tension is created in the dialogue
 • how the dialogue shows the past relationship between the two characters
 • the way in which the dialogue delays talking about the topic at hand
 • how the mood and tone of the characters is represented and how this changes.
